title: Getting Unstuck Day 11: Gusbear remix
description:
For today's challenge, I've remixed my *first ever* Scratch project from 2015. It took me over a week to make this project work how I wanted, at the time!

I specifically chose to remix this project because one of the biggest things I was stuck on when I originally made it was "how to get everything to disappear at once." @karenb happened to come by as I was working, and showed me how to use the broadcast block!

I also want to challenge myself to spend more time thinking about how to integrate Scratch into content-area classrooms for the second and third weeks of Getting Unstuck. When I first encountered Scratch, my main goal was to figure out how to incorporate creative computing into my 6th grade math classroom.
instructions: Click on the green flag and let Gusbear help you practice fractions.

title: Drops (lullabye remix)
description:
Remix of a beautiful Getting Unstuck project by @jsh

I made this to better understand the very clever key changing script used in the original. It uses a list ('chords') to define sets of four-note chords, and plays a few random notes from each as it cycles through the sequence of sets. The effect is a structured harmonic progression that uses new notes on each loop.

I couldn't make sense of the original code, but @jsh answered the question I put in the comments and got me unstuck!
instructions: Green Flag and enjoy.

title: Free Draw! Unstuck Day 11: Broadcast Remix
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #11-remix a broadcast project- of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
For this I remixed one of my 6th grade students' projects. She used broadcast to set the pen color and an erase mode. I added a paintbrush and different pen sizes. I encountered what seems like a Scratch bug where the pen size won't change if triggered by "if this sprite clicked" so instead had to use a variable to set the pen to different sizes. I made the eraser work better by just setting the pen color to white.
instructions: Use the drawing tools to free draw!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 11
description:
This is my project for Day 11 of the Getting Unstuck programming challenge. I found this project and I decided to remix it since it is very simple but cool al the same time. The remix is a very useful feature because it allows you to take the work done by others and modify it according to your needs. It can also be interesting for the author to see which interpretations others have of their own idea.

title: Getting Unstuck Day11
description:
How did remixing help you? I remixed this project from CodeClubRik. I added some more broadcasting to introduce pickles bringing the cup out when the player reaches 5 goals. Remixing meant I had the project foundation to build on, it let me expand what I had time to do beyond the usual basics. 

 What questions do you still have about remixing? None. I love remixing, it's a great way to find answers, get new ideas and understanding/building on someone else's code is a great skill to develop.
instructions:
Player 1:
Use 'space' to kick the ball towards the goal. You have 30 seconds to score as many goals as possible.

Player 2:
Use the left and right arrows to try and stop goals being scored.

title: dice simulator remix
description:
This is a remix of a project I did years ago on my original (non-teacher) Scratch account. I added a way to do 30 quick rolls so the user does not need to click "roll" 30 times. I also added a button to see the current sum of the list.

I love the ability to remix projects! It is a great way to learn how the code for a project works by tinkering with it.

Does anyone teach lessons on remixing? I have not, but I am wondering now if perhaps it would be a good idea to show students how to go about looking inside a remix to learn how it works.
instructions:
Click the green flag to start
The colored boxes allow you to roll the dice or examine the accumulated data.
"clear list" lets you start over

title: Scratch Parade 1 (final)
description:
I would love to share an old project for this Getting Unstuck Challenge, because it really shows the power of cooperation and remixing. To me, this was a very special project. 

Scratch Parade 2 and 3 can be found here:

https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/93959612/

https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/95715008/

Thanks to @schittering06, owner of the Scratch Parade studio, for the great idea to make a Carnival parade. And thanks to these Scratchers for joining: @Dan0510 (3rd wagon), @robnoo (4th), @naccho (5th), @BSGrkdprincess (6th), @bubble103 (7th), @LiFaytheGoblin (8), @vargcity123 (9), @hugmyster (10), @puffleEBP (11), @haras5 (12), @more_bagels (13), @-robox- (14), @schittering06 (15), @moekaroe (16), @Superbatman007 (17), @goodluckchloe (18). @ffred (19), @KeVeg (20), @Silvertail_Studios (21), @RileyPsych (22), @BB8 (23), @yorissen (24), @DerpyLord7 (25), @genny7 (26), @PeanutGuy03 (27), @pixiedus30 (28), @memowpie (29), @Caitlingt3 (30), @chokoji (31), @leszpio (32), @Digitaldesigngirl (33), @scream101 (34) and @suyann (35).

Thanks to the Scratch Team for putting our studio on the frontpage.

Thanks to @ffred, @the_grits and @vargcity123 for the people and to Sergio van Pul en Jessica Chiang for the idea for the robot (I found it in the book Scratch 2.0 Game Development).
instructions:
Scratch is celebrating Carnival with a Scratch Parade, featuring wagons/floats from Scratchers from all over the world! 
A big thanks to everybody who's has made a project for the Scratch Parade. There are contributions from every continent (except Antarctica)! Scratchers from 23 countries have joined!

This is a parade with about 30 wagons. If you want to increase the speed of the parade, please use the slider at the bottom on the right. At the regular speed the whole parade takes about 7 minutes (on my computer - the speed of the Parade depends on the speed of your computer). I hope you enjoy watching it! Making it, together with so many Scratchers, was lots of fun.

Untill January the 29th, the closing date, everybody who wanted could make his or her own wagon and I've added all those floats to my three Scratch Parade. Besides this @schittering06 will share his own Carnival Parade on February the 7th, the first day of Carnival in 2016.

title: Fire Breathing Dragon remix
description:
We were big HP and dragon fans in the day so this early project by daaiyahw6 really caught my eye. I did think that the dragon would be a bit upset at being in the crossfire of the wands so added another broadcast and a click counter to change its response to being pig in the middle. Thanks for the inspriration daaiyahw6!
Remixing is a great way to validate the work of the originator and generating an environment of collaboration.
instructions: Use the magic wands to grow or shrink your dragon! Just press on each wand and see the magic

title: drumbeatz remix
description: thanks to @tyee1 for the original basis of this project.  tyee pointed out that the instruments in one of his projects - drums 2, 6, and 1 -  were falling out of synch. we experimented with different ways of understanding and solving this problem.  although we don't know why it was happening, a solution we discovered was to use broadcast message in order to keep the percussive instruments in synch. Here the project is remixed with new graphix remixed from one of my other old projects for GettingUnstuck day 11.
instructions:

Adjust the tempo while the music is playing

title: Seasons_of_Scratch
description:
First, I thought about the timing of a year in minutes (yesterday's challenge); then, the song from "Rent". Finding downloadable music proved to be a challenge. I purchased the MP3 on Amazon. While viewing the lyrics, I created costumes for some of them. (To get the timing right, I inserted a reset timer block and noted the seconds at different places.) I invested a lot of minutes in working on the timing. 
Credits:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/mwichary/2398136060
https://www.publicdomainpictures.net/en/view-image.php?image=28953&picture=sunset-15
https://pxhere.com/en/photo/1271329

title: Unicorn Maze remix
description:
Credits: This is a remix of the showcase project https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/219998074/ by one of my 4th grade Code Club members.

Reflection:  Perfect timing.  I am gathering examples of my students' work to use in my Scratch@MIT 2018 Conference workshop: Project Management from Design to Showcase. This was a project that struggled to stay on track and be completed in time for the Showcase. I'm reworking it and taking it to a more finished state in order to see how I could have supported the student better.

I tried to stay true to the student's ideas and added some flair of my own.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck #11: Remix a project that uses broadcast.

Click the green flag.  Help the Unicorn get his wings.

title: fill the bucket (shoot the rocket) remix

I remixed an independent project created by one of my students who is passionate about creating in Scratch.

I have been streamlining the code to a basic aim and fire game and will start adding features back later today, when I have more time. I understand someone else's code more when I deconstruct it and focus on one component at a time. 

The other project I considered doing this for war the Sunflower Garden (pen) project by Scratcher scmb1: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/235674874/

title: Snake remix
description: I found this snake game on the home page that used a pretty neat cloning method to draw the snake, but had some bugs that I wanted to address - most importantly it didn't fail when the snake ran into itself. It's always a fun challeng to try and dig into someone else's code and suss out their logical assumptions. Over the course of adding the functionality I initally wanted I also did a bunch of refactoring to simplify the scoring and speeding-up mechanism.

title: Unstuck Day 11 - Crazy Pineapple (remix)
description:
This is a remix. I found this awesome pineapple art/animation with really cool music. I changed some of the graphic effects. I also added the four stars in the corners. Finally I changed the beginning so the pineapple changed size 10 times then added a countdown.

I'm not sure that I completely understand all the variables that were used. I played around with them and saw how the animation changed if I changed numbers in the blocks. That made sense, but I'm not sure that I could have created this code in the first place. I've never created new blocks like Offbeat did, so it was a good learning experience.

Thank you for creating such a cool project, Offbeat.
instructions: Press the flag then press the spacebar.

title: GU#11 - GU Day 10 — Binary Counter (remix)
description:
GettingUnstuck#11 said - "Find a project that uses broadcasting and remix it".

I looked for cool looking projects in GettingUnstuck#10 studio and looked to see what used broadcast. I like the idea of a controller in the original project this is based on. It made me realised that remixing is a good way to look closer at other projects.

My edits are sprite costume based only. This is mainly to add 0 or 1 above the dot so that the binary number is displayed in digit form. More minor - the "on" costume for a bit has a different color.
instructions: Move the slider to change the delay time of the binary counter.

title: The "3 Favorite Things" Pass-It-On Project! remix remix remix remix remix remix remix remix
description:
Reflection

Thanks to all the other remixers of the project that did this before me. It was fun and challenging working inside the same space as others while trying not to break existing work. The most difficult part in doing this remix is that I wanted all my added material to exist within a single sprite so that I wouldn't convolute the project with lots of additional sprites.

One thing I did which was extremely helpful was that I developed most of my contribution in a separate project. Then I moved everything over using the backpack. I had to make a few extra modifications to make it work once it was in this project, but it sped up development quite a bit.
instructions:
Click the green flag to learn about my three favorite things!
Then remix the project to add you and your three favorite things!

title: Spider Web (Unstuck 11)
description:
For this I wanted a light-hearted yet"spooky" type of computational art for this project, and went looking on the Day 11 Studio for inspirations to remix. "Appearing Plants" was such a delight to play and it seemed like the perfect place to start. 

The idea of the "remix" is so liberating, especially with my students, as it totally changes the dynamic of creating and sharing. Rather than being concerned with "getting it right" and being cautious with sharing (or even getting defensive when someone incorporates their solution), they take delight in seeing their creativity and ingeniuity reflected in the projects of their classmates.
instructions: Press the green flag to start.

title: Remix -- Unstuck Challenge 11
description:
This project originally had the cat controlled by the keyboard. This remix alters the controls so that the cat follows the mouse.(I also made minor cosmetic changes to the princesses, giving them each different hair and dress colors.)

Originally, I tried adding a mouse control script from a previous project I created.  I thought it would be a simple drag and drop fix, but it didn't work with the number of sensing scripts in the project.  Instead, I had t develop a new method to have the sprite follow the mouse on click and stop following on clicking the background all while still making use of the color and sprite sensing scripts.  Ultimately, I followed the example of the original project and used the custom block control, which made it much easier to add the necessary code to several scripts.

Remixing was rather fun, as the original creators -  @ECS_Scratcher and rbotero - already had great animations and sensing scripts.
instructions:
Click on Scratch cat and use your mouse to save princess!


From Remix challenge: Find a project that uses broadcasting and remix it. For example, you could remix this pass-it-on project that we started.

This was really difficult. I found it hard finding just the project to remix. Eventually I found this one by @Topsie that I really liked, and thought that I'd just change what it does. 
What I learned from this is that a great way of learning how a project works is to remix it and change one thing at a time. It's certainly a strategy I'll be using with my students.

title: Memory remix Time Dilation: Getting Unstuck Day 11
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 11 Remix

I liked the idea of "energy" as a variable in a project. Yesterday, I tried to implement this idea from scratch in my project but I didn't get very far and abandoned it.
This new project starts as a remix of jsh's Memory project, where I first got the idea for "energy." Rather than trying to remake his wheel, I used his energy variable and applied it to the passage of time and the movement of the Sun across the sky.
Still loving the music, too!
instructions: When you move your mouse around a lot, time advances quickly. When you are still, time advances slowly.

title: Find the Duck! - remix
description:
Remixed from @karenb.
I've made a few changes:
+The background, the character, more costumes and the music are different.
+Coding:  I've added 3 variables: time+ right +wrong choices to make it more challenging; I've added a pixelate effect to make it harder too. 
When you finished it, you can start again if you press the space key.

++This project helped me to understand better how to combine the cloning with variables and randomness. Thanks a lot @karenb for your useful comments.++
instructions:
Press the green flag to start.
Find the random duck.
You have limited time.
Correct duck= + between 5 and 10 secs.
Wrong duck= - 5 secs.


Press the Green Flag to start playing!

title: Unstuck Day 11 Rushing
description: I made this a few years ago and have incorporated it a number of times into my elementary Computer Science curriculum.  I have also included it in a few coding presentations at State and National tech conferences.
instructions:
Click the Green Flag to start an interpretation of Little Miss Muffet.

description:
Thanks to those below for your project. 

I was way behind today, so made this simple.  I tried other projects but they were too complicated.  I felt that this would be simple for my students to use and reference if they needed help when using Scratch.
instructions:
This project demonstrated the broadcast and receive event blocks. 

I use them as cues for the sprites and stage. Notice how I use comments to keep track of what's going on. 

Pay attention also to how I reset everything back to the start with the green flag.

title: Getting Unstuck 11: Pass it On Bees remix
description: I remixed a project that I did on a different account. I changed it so that instead of telling the jokes in the same order every time, the jokes go in a random order. There were a lot of broadcast blocks in the original project, so it took some thinking to get everything to make sense and make sure that the same joke doesn't repeat. I also love that the first bee leaves and is hidden after the second bad joke gets told, so you can't see its reply and the joke-telling bee is just left shouting the punchline.
instructions: Click the green flag to start. Hope you like bad puns!

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 11
description:
This project ended up very different than the one I started remixing.  When I was looking for clipart to use for a sprite I was inspired by "Paint Splat Tree Clipart".

I learned to think and plan ahead.  I made many timely mistakes while stumbling upon the result.

The part that I found the hardest was using the background editor.  I'm not sure when to use Bitmap vs Vector.  I was originally putting the tree and the grass on the background and was pulling in transparent clipart, but the editors were doing funky things.  Later I figured out that I needed the tree to be a sprite so that I could keep it in front of the paint splats.
instructions:
Getting Unstuck Day 11 - Find a project that uses broadcasting and remix it.

Instructions are included in the project.

title: S stands for Spelling
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 11
by Massimo Marletta

I remixed the very nice project by @Ladyra with the following improvements:

- Translated the messages in English.
- Added not Italian letters (J, K, W, X, Y)
- Simplified the word-search routine (it checked manually for all the letters instead of using a cycle).
- Added a second sprite (the Dinosaurs), so now the Cat say the first part of the sentence and the dino say the second part.
- The control is alternated by the two sprites by means of broadcast messages.
- There is a little chance that the Dino say the wrong word. In this case the Cat asks him to repeat the answer and counts the errors.
instructions:
Write you name and the characters will play spelling your name with words. 
Don't expect the Dino is perfect.. maybe if he have known the alphabet, he would not be extinguished now :(

title: Getting Unstuck Day 11
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 11 Reflection:
I started this project for a Scratch class a month or so ago, but I didn't get a chance to finish it.  Is it cheating to remix your own project?!  Remixing helped me save different versions of my project, so I felt a little more comfortable trying different things with it.  I didn't get quite as tangled up in my scripts as I have in other projects.  I don't know how I feel about remixing other projects - I looked for a water cycle one to remix instead of using my own, but I didn't see one I wanted to tinker with.  How do people find projects to remix?  I can see the value in remixing, both for myself and my students, but I didn't find a good search strategy for finding something to remix.
Background image from https://pmm.nasa.gov/education/sites/default/files/article_images/Water-Cycle-Art2A.png.
instructions: Click on the green flag to start, then click on each stage of the water cycle to see what it is..

title: Unstuck #11 Water Cycle
description:
Information: 
https://www.dkit.ie/wow/cycle.php
https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-difference-between-seepage-percolation-and-infiltration
Background:
https://www.storyboardthat.com/lesson-plans/water-cycle
instructions:
This is a remix of a project that I could assign to my elementary school students to demonstrate their learning AND to enable teachers to get comfortable with Scratch. I learned a lot about layers!! 

This project uses broadcast and sounds, and screenshots to make the background interactive. There is a variable that ensures that only one area can be active at a time.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 11 remix remix
description:
The challenge for day 11 was to find a project that uses broadcasting and remix it.  So I searched on twitter for #GettingUnstuck 11 and saw @billmarsland 's video of his program with pugs.  So I decided to switch out all of his pugs for cats.  Then I had to figure out how to change the song at the end. You can't just link it, so that dilemma led me to figure how to convert a youtube url into an mp3!

Kitten images from: https://www.pngarts.com/explore/23435
(Thank you @MrMarslandSF fo posting the links on yours!)

Song from:
https://youtu.be/9RShudgllmY
instructions:
Click on the green flag and let Scratch help you practice fractions.

I remixed this project from @MrMarslandSF who used pugs after remixing @mizzpeters ' version with Corgis. 

(Protip: click on Scratch after he finishes giving instructions if you don't want to do any math problems!)

title: #Unstuck 11 Broadcasting and Remix
description: Thanks to jsh for this idea. I didn't add to hers because I would like my students to add to this.
instructions: Just press the space bar and see if you can add your ideas to this.

title: The "3 Favorite Things" Pass-It-On Project! [tarmelop remix]
description:
This project has a big remix tree, I added myself to the longest branch. It's really challenging to work on the same project with many people! 

I was stuck trying to fix all the bugs I saw in other people's projects, but it would take too much time, so I only fixed some of them (and maybe introduced new others!)

I'm glad to be in such a wonderful company in this project!
instructions: Click the green flag to see all of the characters, then choose a person to learn more about by clicking on their icon!

title: The "3 Favorite Things" Pass-It-On Project! [gmenegoz remix]
description:
I decided to remix Carmelo's project because of his statement about his desire to debug bug introduced by others in this long remix sequence. I said: "I will do it!".
Then of course I gave up and focused on my part, and I got really close to introduce some new bug anyway.
The drawings I used come from a workshop by @wonderfulideaco I had at the Scratch Conference this July. Thank you.
instructions: Click the green flag to see all of the characters, then choose a person to learn more about by clicking on their icon!

title: day11
instructions:
Click the green flag to learn about my three favorite things!
Then remix the project to add you and your three favorite things!

title: The "3 Favorite Things" Pass-It-On Project! [gmenegoz remix] remix
description:
This is an heavy remix of the original project. I refactored the way the script interacts each other (Hope there will no visible differences when running the script)

I added my two cents of favorite things and reworked all the previous sprites: Unified the two sprites in one (There is a limit of ssprite in a project?) and removed the polling cicles of broadcast variable in favor of a message based interaction in order to let the animation a little faster.

It was a long and sometime tedious work but it was satifying at the end ;-)

Feel free to peruse the differences and let's tallk about them in the comments below.
instructions: Click the green flag to see all of the characters, then choose a person to learn more about by clicking on their icon!
